Description: Rim sherd of large Attic black-figured pottery lip cup; interior glazed black; exterior: lip and handle zone reserved with line between; in handle zone painted decoration consisting of part of creature's (probably a seated sphinx's) tail.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
The sherd is one of several examples of lip cups with decoration in the handle zone. For parallels regarding the placement of decoration, see Cambridge Fitzwilliam G66 from Vulci.
Bibliographic references: Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 129, pl. XXXIX, no. 357.9)
CVA Boston II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum USA, Fasc. 19, Museum of Fine Arts, Boston (p. 36-7, pl. 109, no. 7)
Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 234, no. 202)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.1352) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4770 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
